Sorry this got long, but I realized something while writing haha.
TLDR: it's flat writing that ignores its own pre-established logic.

The Kiri scene is such a missed opportunity. But it also highlights that pattern of superficial writing that you bring up here. The films are so vibrant, yet lack flavour - because all nuance is brushed aside and dimmed down. It makes it feel so... Uncanny.

With the Kiri scene, it is clearly intended to show that the humans fail to help her because they do not understand the spiritual aspects of Navi life. However, it has been established in this universe that the connection between the navi's and eywa isn't just spiritual - they're physical connections. You literally plug your nerve ends into the tree 'network'. It is reinforced in both the first and second film: The apex of connection to Eywa is physical. That connection is also what causes Kiri's seizure.

Thematically, it then makes sense to have a schaman help her. But then we need to see this chaman doing something uniquely Navi - connecting to Kiri. Blowing air or chanting isn't what connects you to eywa, jamming your spinal chord into her is.

Then imagine instead: the schamans healing ritual is completed by connecting herself to Kiri - To sprititually and physically dig her out of that locked place she got stuck in during the seizure. We get emphasis on connection, on the blurred lines between spiritual and physical.

But... no. Blowing air it is.

Another similar issue is with the doctor (Norm).
He had great respect for eywa and the navi in previous films, yet here he is dryly stating "Is seizure, it bad, no connect", completely disregarding the fact that eywa as a biological concept, is a belief that the team (led by Grace) shared, or at least respected. Jake himself got permanently transported into his Avatar body using that connection. Why is Norm suddenly all "human science good, navi science bad", when it doesn't fit with his background?

So we have several instances here - in just one scene - of ignoring any nyance that was previously established, in favour of proving the point that the director wants. And preferably it's black and white, with no side of depth.
